document.title: The Euler equations in fluid mechanics

para.p:
Let
Ω
be a domain in
R n
and let
∈ ρ
⁢
C ∞
(
× Ω R
)
; perhaps later we will care about functions that are in larger spaces, and to justify making conclusions about those we will have to check that what we have said here applies to them.

Let
U
be a Lipschitz domain in
Ω
. Thinking of
ρ
as a density, the amount of stuff in
U
at time
t
is

Math.text: (integral _ U)@(rho * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
Let
∈ q
⁢
C ∞
(
× Ω R
)
and
∈ F
⁢
C ∞
(
× Ω R
,
R n
)
. We think about
⁢ q
( x , t )
as the rate at which new stuff appears at point
x
at time
t
, and
F
as the flux of the stuff. A change in the total amount of stuff in
U
occurs from stuff appearing inside
U
and from stuff going through the boundary of
U
. We formalize this as the statement

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ U)@(rho * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ U)@(q * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) - (integral _ (partial-differential@(U)))@(((F * open-interval@(s, t)) cdot N) * s * differential-d@(s))

para.p:
where
⁢ N
( s )
is the outward pointing unit normal to the surface
∂ U
at the point
∈ s
∂ U
. Using the divergence theorem we get

Math.text: (integral _ (partial-differential@(U)))@(((F * open-interval@(s, t)) cdot N) * s * differential-d@(s)) = (integral _ U)@(div * F * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: and hence

Math.text: (integral _ U)@((partial-differential _ t)@(rho) * open-interval@(x, t)) = (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ U)@(rho * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ U)@((q * open-interval@(x, t) - div * F * open-interval@(x, t)) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: or,

Math.text: (integral _ U)@((((partial-differential _ t)@(rho) - q) + div * F) * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
Because this is true for any Lipschitz domain
U
in
Ω
, it follows that the integrand is
0
: for all
∈ x Ω
and
∈ t R
, we have

Math.text: (((partial-differential _ t)@(rho) - q) + div * F) * open-interval@(x, t) = 0

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho) + div * F = q

para.p: This is called a continuity equation.

If
⁢ ρ
( x , t )
denotes the density of stuff at the point
x
at time
t
and
u
denotes the velocity of the stuff at the point
x
and time
t
, then the flux
F
(in other words, the momentum), is
= F
⁢ ρ u
. If there is no stuff spontaneously appearing, but rather stuff only moves around, then
= q 0
, and so

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho) + div * rho * u = 0

para.p: One can describe the statement that stuff is not spontaneously appearing as conservation of mass, and hence () can be thought of as a consequence of conservation of mass.

The integral
∫ U
⁢
(
⁢ ρ u
)
( x , t )
d x
is the total amount of momentum of the stuff at points in
U
at time
t
. We postulate that there is a function
∈ p
⁢
C ∞
( Ω , R )
, which we call pressure, such that the rate of change of the total amount of momentum over a set at time
t
is equal to the flow of momentum from outside to inside the set at time
t
plus the total amount of inward directed pressure over the boundary of the set at time
t
, which here means

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ U)@(rho * u * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) = - (integral _ (partial-differential@(U)))@(((rho * u * open-interval@(s, t) * u * open-interval@(s, t)) cdot N) * s * differential-d@(s)) - (integral _ (partial-differential@(U)))@(p * open-interval@(s, t) * N * s * differential-d@(s))

para.p:
where
⁢ N
( s )
is the outward pointing unit normal to the surface
∂ U
at
∈ s
∂ U
. Using the divergence theorem,

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ U)@(rho * u * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) = - (integral _ U)@(div * ((rho * u) tensor-product u) * open-interval@(x, t)) - (integral _ U)@(nabla@(p) * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: Combined with

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ U)@(rho * u * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x)) = (integral _ U)@(((partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u))@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: this gives

Math.text: (integral _ U)@(((partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + div * ((rho * u) tensor-product u) + nabla@(p)) * open-interval@(x, t) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
Because this is true for any Lipschitz domain
U
in
Ω
, we obtain

Math.text: ((partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + div * ((rho * u) tensor-product u) + nabla@(p)) * open-interval@(x, t) = 0

para.p:
for all
∈ x Ω
and
∈ t R
, or

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + div * ((rho * u) tensor-product u) + nabla@(p) = 0

para.p:
To state that the stuff we are talking about is incompressible means that
ρ
is constant. For the rest of this note, unless we state otherwise we take
ρ
to be a nonzero constant, with which equation () becomes

Math.text: div * u = 0

para.p: and () becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(u) + div * (u tensor-product u) + (1 / rho) * nabla@(p) = 0

para.p: The two equations () and () are called the Euler equations for an incompressible fluid.
Taking the divergence of () yields

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(div) * u + div * div * (u tensor-product u) + (1 / rho) * div * nabla@(p) = 0

para.p:
Using () and writing
=
⁢ Δ p
⁢ div
(
∇ p
)
,

Math.text: div * div * (u tensor-product u) + (1 / rho) * Delta * p = 0

para.p: As

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = ((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j))@(e _ i)

para.p: we have, using (),

Math.text: div * div * (u tensor-product u) = (partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j)) = (partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ j)) = (partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * div * u) = (partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j) = ((partial-differential _ i)@(partial-differential _ j))@(u _ i) * u _ j + (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j) = (partial-differential _ j)@(div * u) * u _ j + (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)
div * div * (u tensor-product u)
(partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j))
(partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ j))
(partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * div * u)
(partial-differential _ i)@((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j)
((partial-differential _ i)@(partial-differential _ j))@(u _ i) * u _ j + (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)
(partial-differential _ j)@(div * u) * u _ j + (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)
(partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)

para.p: Therefore, using this with () we get

Math.text: - Delta * p = rho * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)

para.p:
The use of this equation is to give us more information about the pressure
p
.

Furthermore, with
= u
⁢
u i
e i
and writing

Math.text: nabla@(u) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u) tensor-product e _ j = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j = (partial-differential _ j)@((u _ i * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j)

para.p:
the contraction of the tensor
∇ u
with itself is

Math.text: nabla@(u) * nabla@(u) = (partial-differential _ j)@((u _ i * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j) * (partial-differential _ l)@((u _ k * e _ k) tensor-product e _ l) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ k) * (e _ i tensor-product e _ j) * (e _ k tensor-product e _ l) = ((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ k) * delta _ (list@(j, k)) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ l = ((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ j) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ l
nabla@(u) * nabla@(u)
(partial-differential _ j)@((u _ i * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j) * (partial-differential _ l)@((u _ k * e _ k) tensor-product e _ l)
(partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ k) * (e _ i tensor-product e _ j) * (e _ k tensor-product e _ l)
((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ k) * delta _ (list@(j, k)) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ l
((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ l)@(u _ j) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ l

para.p: for which

Math.text: Tr * nabla@(u) * nabla@(u) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * (partial-differential _ i)@(u _ j)

para.p: With this, equation () becomes

Math.text: - Delta * p = rho * Tr * nabla@(u) * nabla@(u)

para.p: As

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = ((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j))@(e _ i) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j * e _ i + u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ j * e _ i) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j * e _ i + u _ i * div * u * e _ i

para.p: using () we have

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j * e _ i

para.p: and hence it follows from () that

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = u cdot nabla@(u)

para.p:
This expression for
⁢ div
(
⊗ u u
)
may be easier to work with than the original expression.

If
= v
⁢
v i
e i
is a vector field, we write

Math.text: nabla@(v) = (partial-differential _ j)@(v) tensor-product e _ j = ((partial-differential _ j)@(v _ i) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j

para.p: Then,

Math.text: v cdot nabla@(v) = (v _ k * e _ k) cdot (((partial-differential _ j)@(v _ i) * e _ i) tensor-product e _ j) = v _ j * (partial-differential _ j)@(v _ i * e _ i) = v _ j * (partial-differential _ j)@(v)

para.p:
If
u
(velocity of stuff) and
p
(pressure of stuff) satisfy () and (), then applying
u ⋅
to both sides of () we get

Math.text: u cdot (partial-differential _ t)@(u) + (u cdot div) * (u tensor-product u) + ((1 / rho) * u) cdot nabla@(p) = 0

para.p: First,

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(u cdot u) = (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ i * u _ i) = (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ i) * u _ i + u _ i * (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ i) = 2 * u _ i * (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ i) = (2 * u) cdot (partial-differential _ t)@(u)

para.p: Second,

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = ((partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j))@(e _ i)

para.p: so

Math.text: (u cdot div) * (u tensor-product u) = u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ j) = u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ j)

para.p: but

Math.text: div * (u cdot u) * u = div * u _ i * u _ i * u _ j * e _ j = (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i * u _ i * u _ j) = 2 * u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ i) * u _ j + u _ i * u _ i * (partial-differential _ j)@(u _ j)

para.p: hence

Math.text: div * (u cdot u) * u = ((2 * u) cdot div) * (u tensor-product u) - (u cdot u) * div * u

para.p: and using () this is

Math.text: div * (u cdot u) * u = ((2 * u) cdot div) * (u tensor-product u)

para.p: Third,

Math.text: div * p * u = nabla@(p) cdot u + p * div * u

para.p: and using () this is

Math.text: div * p * u = nabla@(p) cdot u

para.p: Putting these three results into () gives

Math.text: (1 / 2) * (partial-differential _ t)@(u cdot u) + (1 / 2) * div * (u cdot u) * u + (1 / rho) * div * p * u = 0

para.p: or

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(((1 / 2) * rho * u) cdot u) + div * ((1 / 2) * rho * (u cdot u) * u + p * u) = 0

para.p: We define

Math.text: E = ((1 / 2) * rho * u) cdot u

para.p:
If
ρ
is thought of as mass density, with units of
/ kg
m 3
, and
u
is thought of as the velocity of stuff, with units of
/ m s
, then
E
has units of
=
⁢ kg
m
- 1
s
- 2
/ J
m 3
. We choose to think of
E
defined this way as energy density; we say choose because although
E
has the right units to be energy density, any multiple would have the same units, and it is not apparent from what we have said so far why we care about
⋅
⁢
1 2
ρ u
u
rather than some other multiple of
⋅
⁢ ρ u
u
. Writing equation () using
E
gives

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(E) + div * (E * u + p * u) = 0

para.p:
which is thus a statement about the rate of change of energy density. We call
+ E p
ρ
the total specific enthalpy of the stuff. To say that a quantity is specific means that it expresses some quantity per
kg
, and the dimensions of enthalpy are
J
.

In this section, unless we say otherwise we take
= n 3
. For vector fields
v , w
,

Math.text: nabla@(v cdot w) = v cdot nabla@(w) + w cdot nabla@(v) + v * curl * w + w * curl * v

para.p:
Using this identity
= v u
and
= w u
gives

Math.text: u cdot nabla@(u) = u * curl * u - (1 / 2) * nabla@(u cdot u)

para.p: and therefore () can be written as

Math.text: div * (u tensor-product u) = (1 / 2) * nabla@(u cdot u) - u * curl * u

para.p: Taking the curl of () yields

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(curl * u) + curl * div * (u tensor-product u) = 0

para.p:
we used the fact that the curl of the gradient of any scalar field is
0
and so
=
⁢ curl
∇ p
0
. Using (), this becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(curl) * u + curl * ((1 / 2) * nabla@(u cdot u) - u * curl * u) = 0

para.p:
and as the curl of the gradient of a scalar field is
0
, this is

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(curl * u) = curl * u * curl * u

para.p:
For vector fields
v , w
,

Math.text: curl * v * w = ((v * div * w - w * div * v) + nabla@(v) * w) - nabla@(w) * v

para.p:
and with
= v u
and
= w
⁢ curl u
we obtain

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(curl * u) = ((u * div * curl * u - curl * u * div * u) + nabla@(u) * curl * u) - nabla@(curl * u) * u

para.p:
Because the divergence of the curl of a vector field is
0
and because
=
⁢ div u
0
by (), this becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(curl * u) = nabla@(u) * curl * u - nabla@(curl * u) * u

para.p:
We call
= ω
⁢ curl
( u )
the vorticity of the stuff, and with this notation the above equation can be written as

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(omega) = nabla@(u) * omega - nabla@(omega) * u

para.p:
One often deals with expressions like
+
∂ t
ω
⋅ u
∇ ω
, and we write

Math.text: D / (D * t) = partial-differential _ t + u cdot nabla

para.p:
and call
D
⁢ D t
the material time derivative; it depends on the velocity
u
of the stuff. With this notation, the equation () is

Math.text: (D * omega) / (D * t) = omega cdot nabla@(u)

para.p: Using () (which itself supposes ()), we can write () using the material time derivative as

Math.text: (D * u) / (D * t) + nabla@(p) = 0

para.p:
In this section unless we say otherwise we take
= n 3
and we suppose that
=
⁢ curl u
0
, which we describe as
u
being irrotational. We suppose also in this section that
Ω
is simply connected, which together with
=
⁢ curl u
0
implies that there is some
∈ ϕ
⁢
C ∞
(
× Ω R
)
for which

Math.text: u * open-interval@(x, t) = nabla@(phi) * open-interval@(x, t)

para.p:
for all
∈ x Ω
and for all
∈ t R
; cf. the Helmholtz decomposition of a vector field in
R 3
. We call
ϕ
a potential function for
u
. Combining (), (), and
= u
∇ ϕ
, we obtain

Math.text: ((partial-differential _ t)@(nabla))@(phi) + nabla@(phi) cdot (nabla@(nabla))@(phi) + (1 / rho) * nabla@(p) = 0

para.p: We have

Math.text: nabla@(phi) cdot (nabla@(nabla))@(phi) = (partial-differential _ i)@(phi * e _ i) cdot nabla@((partial-differential _ k)@(phi * e _ k)) = (partial-differential _ i)@(phi * e _ i) cdot ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@((phi * e _ k) tensor-product e _ j) = (partial-differential _ i)@(phi) * ((partial-differential _ i)@(partial-differential _ k))@(phi * e _ k) = (1 / 2) * ((partial-differential _ k)@((partial-differential _ i)@(phi) * (partial-differential _ i)@(phi)))@(e _ k) = (1 / 2) * ((partial-differential _ k)@(nabla@(phi) cdot nabla@(phi)))@(e _ k) = (1 / 2) * nabla@(nabla@(phi) cdot nabla@(phi))
nabla@(phi) cdot (nabla@(nabla))@(phi)
(partial-differential _ i)@(phi * e _ i) cdot nabla@((partial-differential _ k)@(phi * e _ k))
(partial-differential _ i)@(phi * e _ i) cdot ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@((phi * e _ k) tensor-product e _ j)
(partial-differential _ i)@(phi) * ((partial-differential _ i)@(partial-differential _ k))@(phi * e _ k)
(1 / 2) * ((partial-differential _ k)@((partial-differential _ i)@(phi) * (partial-differential _ i)@(phi)))@(e _ k)
(1 / 2) * ((partial-differential _ k)@(nabla@(phi) cdot nabla@(phi)))@(e _ k)
(1 / 2) * nabla@(nabla@(phi) cdot nabla@(phi))

para.p: with which () becomes

Math.text: ((partial-differential _ t)@(nabla))@(phi) + (1 / 2) * nabla@(nabla@(phi) cdot nabla@(phi)) + (1 / rho) * nabla@(p) = 0

para.p: or

Math.text: nabla@((partial-differential _ t)@(phi) + ((1 / 2) * nabla@(phi)) cdot nabla@(phi) + (1 / rho) * p) = 0

para.p:
Then, defining
P
to be

Math.text: P = (partial-differential _ t)@(phi) + ((1 / 2) * nabla@(phi)) cdot nabla@(phi) + (1 / rho) * p

para.p:
we have that
P
depends only on time. We call
P
the total pressure, and the statement that the total pressure depends only on time if the velocity
u
is irrotational is called Bernoulli’s principle.

Furthermore, combining () with
= u
∇ ϕ
gives

Math.text: Delta * phi = 0

para.p:
i.e., for each
∈ t R
,
↦ x
⁢ ϕ
( x , t )
is a harmonic function on
Ω
.

In this section we take
= n 1
and do not suppose that the pressure
ρ
is constant. Since we do not take
ρ
to be constant, we will use (), which tells us that

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho) + div * rho * u = 0

para.p: and (), which tells us that

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + div * ((rho * u) tensor-product u) + nabla@(p) = 0

para.p:
As
= n 1
here, we can write these two equations as

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho * u) = 0

para.p: and

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho * u ^ 2) + (partial-differential _ x)@(p) = 0

para.p:
We suppose, giving no justification, that there are some constant
K
and
γ
for which
= p
⁢ K
ρ γ
. With this assumption, equation () becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho * u) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho * u ^ 2) + gamma * (p / rho) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho) = 0

para.p:
We write
= ρ
+
ρ 0
ρ 1
where
ρ 0
is a constant, and we also write
= u
+
u 0
u 1
where
u 0
is a constant. With these definitions, the equation () becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 0 + rho _ 1) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 0 * u _ 0 + rho _ 0 * u _ 1 + rho _ 1 * u _ 0 + rho _ 1 * u _ 1) = 0

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 1) + rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) + u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1 * u _ 1) = 0

para.p: Supposing that the last term is negligible, an approximation to the above equation is

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 1) + rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) + u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) = 0

para.p: Furthermore, () becomes

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 0 * u _ 0 + rho _ 0 * u _ 1 + rho _ 1 * u _ 0 + rho _ 1 * u _ 1) + (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 0 * (u _ 0) ^ 2 + 2 * rho _ 0 * u _ 0 * u _ 1 + rho _ 0 * (u _ 1) ^ 2 + rho _ 1 * (u _ 0) ^ 2 + 2 * rho _ 1 * u _ 0 * u _ 1 + rho _ 0 * (u _ 1) ^ 2) + gamma * (p / (rho _ 0 + rho _ 1)) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 0 + rho _ 1) = 0

para.p:
Using that
ρ 0
and
u 0
are constant and supposing that
∂ x
(
⁢
ρ 1
u 1
)
and
∂ x
(
u 1
2
)
are negligible gives us the approximation

Math.text: rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ 1) + u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 1) + 2 * rho _ 0 * u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) + (u _ 0) ^ 2 * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) + gamma * (p / (rho _ 0 + rho _ 1)) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1)

para.p:
Expressing
1
+
ρ 0
ρ 1
as a geometric series in powers of
ρ 1
ρ 0
and supposing that the sum of all the nonconstant terms is negligible, and approximating
= p
⁢ K
ρ γ
as
=
p 0
⁢ K
ρ 0
γ
gives us the approximation

Math.text: rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ 1) + u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ t)@(rho _ 1) + 2 * rho _ 0 * u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) + (u _ 0) ^ 2 * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) + gamma * (p _ 0 / rho _ 0) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) = 0

para.p:
Combining this equation with () multiplied by
u 0
yields

Math.text: rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ t)@(u _ 1) + rho _ 0 * u _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) + gamma * (p _ 0 / rho _ 0) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) = 0

para.p:
We define
=
D t
+
∂ t
⁢
u 0
∂ x
, with which we can write the above equation as

Math.text: rho _ 0 * D _ t * u _ 1 + gamma * (p _ 0 / rho _ 0) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1) = 0

para.p: and we can write () as

Math.text: D _ t * rho _ 1 + rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(u _ 1) = 0

para.p:
Applying
D t
to () gives

Math.text: (D _ t) ^ 2 * rho _ 1 + rho _ 0 * (partial-differential _ x)@(D _ t * u _ 1) = 0

para.p: and then using () this becomes

Math.text: (D _ t) ^ 2 * rho _ 1 + (partial-differential _ x)@(- gamma * (p _ 0 / rho _ 0) * (partial-differential _ x)@(rho _ 1)) = 0

para.p: or

Math.text: (D _ t) ^ 2 * rho _ 1 - gamma * (p _ 0 / rho _ 0) * ((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2)@(rho _ 1) = 0

para.p:
which is a wave equation satisfied by
ρ 1
.
